results.title: The Common cold
results.brief_description: Illustrates the facts known about the common cold, its care, and secondary infections that may grow out of it. Tells the story of a boy who contracts a cold and visits his doctor for treatment and advice. Reveals by means of the doctor’s illustrated explanation, why the common cold is serious and how it should be treated.

results.title: Come see the dolphins
results.creator_credit: Tom Ascher and Coronet Instructional Media
results.brief_description: Presents the story of a young boy who accompanies his father, a dolphin keeper, to the zoo to see the dolphins. The boy learns of the appearance of dolphins, what they eat and how they communicate and navigate. Skillful photography includes observations underwater and behind the scenes views of equipment and workers needed to maintain the dolphin pool.

results.title: Coma
results.creator_credit: Ray Argall, British Petroleum and St John Ambulance Australia
results.brief_description:
Coma can be caused by epilspsy, drowning, drug overdose or head injuries. Shows what to do for people in a deep coma. The victim should be moved into the approved coma position until medical help arrives. It is the only treatment that a first aider can and should apply.

PLEASE NOTE: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date first-aid practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: The Columbia River
results.brief_description: A survey of the Columbia River System, the world’s largest single source of hydroelectric power. Shows the multi-purpose dams, discusses US-Canadian agreements for further development, and explains the value of the waterway in irrigation, navigation and flood control.

results.title: The Color of man
results.creator_credit: Robert Carl Cohen and University of California, Los Angeles
results.brief_description: Explains the reason for variation in skin color of people of the different nationalities. The film describes how in prehistoric times humans living near the equator could not protect themselves from the direct ultra-violent rays of the sun, and did not survive unless they developed a protective pigment in their skin known as melanin. Similarly those living away from the direct ultra-violet developed a fair skin which permitted the rays to penetrate, for a certain amount of ultra-violet light is essential for life. Narrated by Robert Doubleday.
